sections.title: 4. Types of Anaphoric Reference to Noun Phrases 4.1 Denotational Anaphora
paragraphs: In both of the two types of pronominal anaphora considered so far, reference and bound variable anaphora, there is a direct mapplnE from pronouns To discourse referents, and another one from discourse referent to individual constant or varlable in the loEical representation. A consTant stands for a real object in the world, and a variable will stand for one at evaluation time; This object is the denotation of the pronoun. For this reason both types of anaphora considered so far are usually called "denotatlonal anaphora". This name is unfortunate as it blurs the main idea behind this type of anaphora, viz. The fact that "denotaTional anaphora" is an abstraction of referential (or: denotatlonal) and non-referentlal (or: bound variable) uses of pronouns and other noun phrases. It would be much better to speak of extensional anaphora instead.

i. We treat truly Eenerlc sentences, such as 15, and ~eneral sentences, such as 16, on a par. This is, of course, a Eross simplification. Furthermore, it would be more precise to say, instead of "variable", "an expression contain-inE variables" (to include Skolem-Functions). In Ereater detail: cf. Hess 1985.
